articles.title: Ancient artists created giant camel engravings in the Arabian desert
articles.summary: Almost 200 engravings created around 12,000 years ago have been discovered in Saudi Arabia, including depictions of camels etched into cliff faces over 40 metres high
articles.content:
Almost 200 engravings created around 12,000 years ago have been discovered in Saudi Arabia, including depictions of camels etched into cliff faces over 40 metres high

A life-sized camel engraving at Jebel Misma, Saudi Arabia Sahout Rock Art and Archaeology Project

Ancient inhabitants of the Arabian desert created monumental works of rock art on cliff faces, including life-sized images of camels, perhaps as a way to mark sources of water.

Michael Petraglia, at Griffith University in Brisbane, Australia, and his colleagues discovered 176 engravings on 62 panels in the Nefud desert in Saudi Arabia in 2023. There are 90 life-sized images of camels, another 15 smaller camel engravings and two camel footprints.

One of the rock art sites, featuring a 3-metre-tall dromedary, was more than 40 metres up the cliff and impossible for members of the team to safely reach and survey without deploying a drone.

“It would have been dangerous to make these engravings,” says Petraglia. “There’s no way I would go up there.”

Alongside the camels, and highlighting how much more benign the climate must have been, are other large animals including ibex, horses, gazelles and aurochs. The team also found engraved human figures and face masks.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

“It’s not just doodling or marking the landscape,” says Petraglia. “These are engravings of things that would have been iconic for them culturally.”

The researchers say the images were possibly carved to warn any outsiders that the land was already occupied or to act as a signpost for ephemeral water sources. The new discoveries add to evidence of extensive past occupation of Saudi Arabia in prehistoric times.

Indicating the antiquity of the images, a natural varnish had formed over the engravings, a process that researchers know would have taken around 8000 years. However, it wasn’t possible to directly date the artwork, so the team excavated in the sediments under the rock art panels.

Excavation of a trench directly beneath a rock art panel at Jebel Arnaan, where engraving tools were discovered Sahout Rock Art and Archaeology Project

There, they found stone points, beads and ochres indicating links with Late Neolithic people in the Levant, as well as tools that would have been used to make the engravings. These objects were able to be dated and ranged in age from 12,800 to 11,400 years old.

Excavations were also undertaken in the small temporary lakes, called playas, near the engravings, which the ancient people would have relied on. Sediments and pollen records confirmed that the region would have been much wetter and greener.

But, even so, the environment was challenging and unlikely to be a place where people could settle and stay for long periods of time, says Petraglia.

“These were likely very mobile people and highly innovative,” he says. “These are sophisticated hunter-gatherers and definitely not people just sort of figuring it out.”

Journal reference: Nature Communications DOI: 10.1038/s41467-025-63417-y
articles.reasoning: The discovery of ancient giant camel engravings in Saudi Arabia reveals significant archaeological and cultural insights about prehistoric human life and environment, offering broad educational and historical value to society. The findings highlight human innovation and adaptation, enriching our understanding of ancient civilizations with substantial context and detail.
articles.personality_title: Ancient giant camel engravings found in Saudi Arabian desert cliffs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around 12,000 years ago, people lived in what is now the Saudi Arabian desert. This area was wetter and greener back then, supporting animals and human life. 

**What happened** – In 2023, researchers led by Michael Petraglia discovered nearly 200 rock engravings carved into cliffs in the Nefud desert. Among these were 90 life-sized images of camels, including one 3-metre-tall camel carved over 40 metres high on a cliff face. The team also found engravings of other animals like ibex and horses, as well as human figures and face masks. 

**Impact** – These engravings show that ancient people in the desert were skilled artists and had strong cultural connections to camels and other animals. The size and location of the carvings suggest they were important markers, possibly to show where water sources were or to warn others that the land was occupied. The finds give us new information about how people lived and moved in a challenging environment thousands of years ago.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue studying the engravings and nearby sites to learn more about the tools used to make them and the lives of these ancient hunter-gatherers. They hope to better understand how climate changes affected human life in the Arabian desert over time.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Ancient giant camel carvings in Saudi Arabia reveal skilled artistry and important cultural signs from people living in a greener desert 12,000 years ago.
articles.personality_title_fr: D’anciens gravures géantes de chameaux découvertes dans les falaises du désert saoudien
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 12 000 ans, des peuples vivaient dans ce qui est aujourd’hui le désert saoudien, une région alors plus humide et verdoyante, abritant animaux et humains.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2023, une équipe menée par Michael Petraglia a découvert près de 200 gravures rupestres sur des falaises du désert de Nefud. Parmi elles, 90 images grandeur nature de chameaux, dont un chameau de 3 mètres gravé à plus de 40 mètres de hauteur. Ils ont aussi trouvé des gravures d’autres animaux comme des bouquetins et des chevaux, ainsi que des figures humaines et des masques.

**Impact** – Ces gravures montrent que les anciens habitants du désert étaient des artistes habiles et que les chameaux avaient une grande importance culturelle. La taille et l’emplacement des gravures suggèrent qu’elles servaient à indiquer des sources d’eau ou à signaler que le territoire était occupé. Ces découvertes apportent de nouvelles informations sur la vie et les déplacements dans un environnement difficile il y a des milliers d’années.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier les gravures et les sites voisins pour mieux comprendre les outils utilisés et la vie de ces chasseurs-cueilleurs anciens. Ils veulent aussi mieux saisir l’impact des changements climatiques sur la vie humaine dans le désert arabique.

**Phrase clé** – Les gravures géantes de chameaux en Arabie Saoudite révèlent une grande habileté artistique et des signes culturels importants datant d’un désert plus vert il y a 12 000 ans.
articles.personality_title_es: Descubren antiguas grabados gigantes de camellos en acantilados del desierto saudí
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 12,000 años, personas vivían en lo que hoy es el desierto de Arabia Saudita, una zona que entonces era más húmeda y verde, con animales y humanos.

**Qué pasó** – En 2023, un equipo liderado por Michael Petraglia encontró casi 200 grabados en rocas en el desierto de Nefud. Entre ellos, 90 imágenes de camellos a tamaño real, incluyendo uno de 3 metros tallado a más de 40 metros de altura en un acantilado. También hallaron grabados de otros animales como íbices y caballos, además de figuras humanas y máscaras.

**Impacto** – Estos grabados muestran que las personas antiguas del desierto eran artistas expertos y que los camellos tenían un gran valor cultural. El tamaño y la ubicación indican que servían para marcar fuentes de agua o para avisar que el territorio estaba ocupado. Estas hallazgos nos dan nueva información sobre cómo vivían y se movían en un ambiente difícil hace miles de años.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando los grabados y lugares cercanos para aprender más sobre las herramientas usadas y la vida de estos cazadores-recolectores antiguos. Quieren entender mejor cómo los cambios climáticos afectaron la vida humana en el desierto árabe.

**Frase clave** – Los grabados gigantes de camellos en Arabia Saudita revelan arte hábil y señales culturales importantes de un desierto más verde hace 12,000 años.

articles.title: New EU budget: Save and invest – like in Sweden
articles.summary: Sweden is seen as a model when the EU Commission calls for savings and investment accounts to free up more money for growth in Europe.
articles.content:
Sweden is seen as a model when the EU Commission calls for savings and investment accounts to free up more money for growth in Europe.

Brussels – The EU Commission calls for savings and investment accounts to unlock more money for growth in Europe.

A strategy to make Europeans more “financially literate” is being launched alongside a “blueprint” on how savings and investment accounts can be established. Sweden is seen as a model.

The hope is that the billions currently frozen in regular savings accounts can instead be used to finance various initiatives in the business sector, thereby benefiting both savers and growth.

“For many Europeans, investments are seen as incomprehensible, unclear, and only for those with large disposable assets,” says Maria Luís Albuquerque, EU Commissioner for financial affairs and investments, at a press conference in Brussels.

In Sweden, there are so-called investment savings accounts, ISK accounts, where savings of up to 150,000 kronor are tax-free. From 2026, that limit will be raised to 300,000 kronor. The purpose of ISK is to save in stocks and funds. Profits from stock or fund sales can be withdrawn tax-free.

(September 30)
articles.reasoning: The EU Commission's initiative to promote savings and investment accounts modeled after Sweden's tax-free investment savings accounts aims to increase financial literacy and unlock significant funds for economic growth across Europe. This has broad societal and economic benefits by encouraging investment and supporting business growth, impacting many Europeans positively.
articles.personality_title: EU plans savings and investment accounts inspired by Sweden to boost growth
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union wants to help people save and invest money more easily. Many Europeans keep money in regular savings accounts, but these do not help the economy grow much.

**What happened** – The EU Commission announced a plan to create special savings and investment accounts, similar to those in Sweden. In Sweden, these accounts let people invest in stocks and funds without paying taxes on their profits up to a certain amount. The EU also wants to teach people more about how to manage money and invest wisely.

**Impact** – This plan could unlock billions of euros that are now sitting unused in regular savings accounts. By encouraging investments, it can help businesses get more money to grow and create jobs. It also makes investing less confusing and more accessible for many people who think it is only for the rich.

**What's next step** – The EU will work on creating rules for these accounts and start programs to teach financial skills. If successful, more countries in Europe might offer similar accounts, helping more people save and invest smarter.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU aims to boost economic growth by promoting tax-free investment accounts and better money skills, using Sweden's model as a guide.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE propose des comptes d’épargne et d’investissement inspirés de la Suède pour stimuler la croissance
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne souhaite aider les citoyens à mieux épargner et investir leur argent. Beaucoup d’Européens gardent leur argent sur des comptes d’épargne classiques, qui ne favorisent pas beaucoup la croissance économique.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Commission européenne a annoncé un plan pour créer des comptes d’épargne et d’investissement spéciaux, similaires à ceux existant en Suède. En Suède, ces comptes permettent d’investir en actions et fonds sans payer d’impôts sur les gains jusqu’à un certain montant. L’UE veut aussi mieux informer les gens sur la gestion de l’argent et l’investissement.

**Impact** – Ce plan pourrait débloquer des milliards d’euros qui restent inutilisés sur des comptes classiques. Encourager l’investissement aidera les entreprises à obtenir plus d’argent pour se développer et créer des emplois. Cela rend aussi l’investissement plus clair et accessible à ceux qui pensent que c’est réservé aux riches.

**Prochaine étape** – L’UE va travailler à la création de règles pour ces comptes et lancer des programmes d’éducation financière. Si ça marche, d’autres pays européens pourraient proposer des comptes similaires, aidant plus de personnes à mieux épargner et investir.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’UE veut stimuler la croissance économique en promouvant des comptes d’investissement sans impôts et en améliorant les compétences financières, en s’inspirant du modèle suédois.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE propone cuentas de ahorro e inversión al estilo Suecia para impulsar el crecimiento
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea quiere ayudar a las personas a ahorrar e invertir dinero de forma más fácil. Muchos europeos guardan su dinero en cuentas de ahorro normales, que no ayudan mucho al crecimiento económico.

**Qué pasó** – La Comisión Europea anunció un plan para crear cuentas especiales de ahorro e inversión, parecidas a las de Suecia. En Suecia, estas cuentas permiten invertir en acciones y fondos sin pagar impuestos sobre las ganancias hasta cierto límite. La UE también quiere enseñar a la gente a manejar mejor su dinero e invertir con conocimiento.

**Impacto** – Este plan podría liberar miles de millones de euros que ahora están sin usar en cuentas normales. Al fomentar la inversión, puede ayudar a que las empresas tengan más dinero para crecer y crear empleos. Además, hace que invertir sea menos confuso y más accesible para muchas personas que creen que solo es para ricos.

**Próximo paso** – La UE trabajará en las reglas para estas cuentas y lanzará programas para enseñar habilidades financieras. Si tiene éxito, más países europeos podrían ofrecer cuentas similares, ayudando a más personas a ahorrar e invertir mejor.

**Frase clave** – La UE busca impulsar el crecimiento económico promoviendo cuentas de inversión sin impuestos y mejorando la educación financiera, usando el modelo sueco como ejemplo.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a golden nest filled with shining coins and small, stylized stock certificates gently glowing, resting beside a calm Nordic lake under soft natural light, symbolizing Sweden’s tax-free investment savings accounts nurturing financial growth and stability in Europe.
